Expectation1: Communicate any challenges or concerns promptly to the mentor.
Situation1: The mentee has a small question about terminology that isn't blocking their work.
Expectation2: Communicate with clients and vendors regarding financial matters.
Situation2: A major supplier has threatened to halt all future shipments until a significant past-due invoice is settled.
Story: I sat at my desk, staring at the blinking cursor on my email draft. As a mentee, I knew I was supposed to reach out to my mentor whenever I hit a snag, no matter how small. Today, I stumbled over a term in the new accounting software—nothing urgent, but I could hear my mentor’s voice in my head: “Don’t hesitate to ask, even about the little things.” At the same time, my phone buzzed with a message from our major supplier, their tone unmistakably stern. They wouldn’t ship another box until we paid the overdue invoice. As the accountant, it was my job to handle these financial fires, to keep the business running smoothly. My mind raced, torn between the expectation to be a proactive mentee and the pressing demand to resolve a crisis that could halt our operations. I felt the weight of both roles pressing in, each demanding my immediate attention, and I hesitated, caught in the tension of choosing which responsibility to address first.
